nodes.label: Recognize connections and causal relation
nodes.text: recognize connections and causal relation (inductive, deductive, and analogical reasoning is activated)

nodes.label: Data reasoning
nodes.text: Data reasoning: analysing data to make grounded conclusions
nodes.citation: Masnick, A. M., & Morris, B. J. (2022). A Model of Scientific Data Reasoning. Education Sciences, 12(2), 71. https://doi.org/10.3390/educsci12020071

nodes.label: Biological reasoning
nodes.text: Biological reasoning: experimental evaluation relates to empirical investigations to establish patterns, differentiate objects, and test predictions
nodes.citation: Schellinger, J., Enderle, P. J., Roberts, K., Skrob-Martin, S., Rhemer, D., & Southerland, S. A. (2021). Describing the Development of the Assessment of Biological Reasoning (ABR). Education Sciences, 11(11), 669. https://doi.org/10.3390/educsci11110669

nodes.label: Evolutionary reasoning
nodes.citation: Kind, P., & Osborne, J. (2017). Styles of Scientific Reasoning: A Cultural Rationale for Science Education? Science Education, 101(1), 8–31. https://doi.org/10.1002/sce.21251

nodes.label: Reasoning about change and relationships
nodes.citation: OECD. (2018). The Future of Education and Skills: Education 2030. Position Paper. http://www.oecd.org/education/2030/E2030%20Position%20Paper%20(05.04.2018).pdf

nodes.label: Pattern recognition and decomposition
nodes.text: pattern recognition, decomposition, determining which (if any) computing tools could be employed in the analysing or solving the problem, and defining algorithms as part of a detailed solution
nodes.citation: OECD. (2018). The Future of Education and Skills: Education 2030. Position Paper. http://www.oecd.org/education/2030/E2030%20Position%20Paper%20(05.04.2018).pdf

nodes.label: Computational thinking
nodes.text: Computational thinking is using abstraction and decomposition when attacking a large complex task or designing a large complex system
nodes.citation: Wing, J. (2006). Computational Thinking. Communications of the ACM, 49(3), 33–35. https://doi.org/10.1145/1118178.1118215

nodes.label: Mathematical deduction
nodes.citation: Kind, P., & Osborne, J. (2017). Styles of Scientific Reasoning: A Cultural Rationale for Science Education? Science Education, 101(1), 8–31. https://doi.org/10.1002/sce.21251

nodes.label: Judging continuity and change
nodes.text: Judging about continuity and change, thus understanding individual elements and their relationships
nodes.citation: Seixas, P., & Morton, T. (2012). The Big Six Historical Thinking Concepts. Toronto: Nelson.

nodes.label: Argumentation through analysis
nodes.citation: van Boxtel, C., & van Drie, J. (2018). Historical reasoning: Conceptualizations and educational applications. In The Wiley International Handbook of History Teaching and Learning (pp. 149–176). Hoboken: WileyBlackwell. https://doi.org/10.1002/9781119100812.ch6

nodes.label: Identify constituent parts and functions
nodes.text: Identify constituent parts and functions of a process or concept, or de-construct a methodology or process, making qualitative assessment of elements, relationships, values and effects; measure requirements or needs
nodes.citation: Wrigley, C., & Straker, K. (2015). Design Thinking pedagogy: The Educational Design Ladder. Innovations in Education and Teaching International, 54(4), 374–385. https://doi.org/10.1080/14703297.2015.1108214

nodes.label: Evaluating info
nodes.text: evaluating info (of various types or forms)

nodes.label: Making decisions
nodes.text: making decisions (inductive, deductive, and analogical reasoning is activated)

nodes.label: Experimental evaluation
nodes.text: Experimental evaluation, e.g., in Biological reasoning and in other sciences
nodes.source: Schellinger et al. 2021; Kind and Osborne 2017
nodes.citation: Schellinger, J., Enderle, P. J., Roberts, K., Skrob-Martin, S., Rhemer, D., & Southerland, S. A. (2021). Describing the Development of the Assessment of Biological Reasoning (ABR). Education Sciences, 11(11), 669. https://doi.org/10.3390/educsci11110669; Kind, P., & Osborne, J. (2017). Styles of Scientific Reasoning: A Cultural Rationale for Science Education? Science Education, 101(1), 8–31. https://doi.org/10.1002/sce.21251

nodes.label: Data reasoning for decisions
nodes.text: Data reasoning on available quantitative data: evaluating it to make decisions
nodes.citation: Masnick, A. M., & Morris, B. J. (2022). A Model of Scientific Data Reasoning. Education Sciences, 12(2), 71. https://doi.org/10.3390/educsci12020071

nodes.label: Evaluate explanations
nodes.text: Recognise, offer, and evaluate explanations for a range of natural and technological phenomena
nodes.citation: OECD. (2013). PISA 2012 Assessment and Analytical Framework: Mathematics, Reading, Science, Problem Solving and Financial Literacy, PISA. Paris: OECD Publishing. https://doi.org/10.1787/9789264190511-en

nodes.label: Mathematical reasoning judgments
nodes.text: [mathematical reasoning] includes making judgements about the validity of information that bombards individuals by means of considering their quantitative and logical, implications
nodes.citation: OECD. (2018). The Future of Education and Skills: Education 2030. Position Paper. http://www.oecd.org/education/2030/E2030%20Position%20Paper%20(05.04.2018).pdf

nodes.label: Interpret and evaluate
nodes.text: interpret and evaluate, evaluate the mathematical solution
nodes.citation: OECD. (2018). The Future of Education and Skills: Education 2030. Position Paper. http://www.oecd.org/education/2030/E2030%20Position%20Paper%20(05.04.2018).pdf

nodes.label: Reasoning about quantity
nodes.text: Reasoning about quantity [that is in basic level comparing quantity]
nodes.citation: OECD. (2018). The Future of Education and Skills: Education 2030. Position Paper. http://www.oecd.org/education/2030/E2030%20Position%20Paper%20(05.04.2018).pdf

nodes.label: Evaluation of evidence
nodes.citation: Seixas, P., & Morton, T. (2012). The Big Six Historical Thinking Concepts. Toronto: Nelson.

nodes.label: Assessing ethical dimension
nodes.citation: Seixas, P., & Morton, T. (2012). The Big Six Historical Thinking Concepts. Toronto: Nelson.

nodes.label: Historical significance evaluation
nodes.text: Historical significance: evaluation aspect of this concept
nodes.citation: Seixas, P., & Morton, T. (2012). The Big Six Historical Thinking Concepts. Toronto: Nelson.

nodes.label: Argumentation through evaluation
nodes.citation: van Boxtel, C., & van Drie, J. (2018). Historical reasoning: Conceptualizations and educational applications. In The Wiley International Handbook of History Teaching and Learning (pp. 149–176). Hoboken: WileyBlackwell. https://doi.org/10.1002/9781119100812.ch6

nodes.label: Assess effectiveness
nodes.text: Assess effectiveness of whole concepts, in relation to values, outputs, efficacy, viability
nodes.citation: Wrigley, C., & Straker, K. (2015). Design Thinking pedagogy: The Educational Design Ladder. Innovations in Education and Teaching International, 54(4), 374–385. https://doi.org/10.1080/14703297.2015.1108214

nodes.label: Strategic comparison and review
nodes.citation: Wrigley, C., & Straker, K. (2015). Design Thinking pedagogy: The Educational Design Ladder. Innovations in Education and Teaching International, 54(4), 374–385. https://doi.org/10.1080/14703297.2015.1108214

nodes.label: Interpreting
nodes.text: interpreting (inductive, deductive, and analogical reasoning can be activated during these activities)

nodes.label: Hypothesising and modelling
nodes.citation: Kind, P., & Osborne, J. (2017). Styles of Scientific Reasoning: A Cultural Rationale for Science Education? Science Education, 101(1), 8–31. https://doi.org/10.1002/sce.21251

nodes.label: Biological reasoning modelling
nodes.text: in natural sciences; e.g., as a part of Biological reasoning (hypothetical modelling relates to the construction of models)
nodes.citation: Schellinger, J., Enderle, P. J., Roberts, K., Skrob-Martin, S., Rhemer, D., & Southerland, S. A. (2021). Describing the Development of the Assessment of Biological Reasoning (ABR). Education Sciences, 11(11), 669. https://doi.org/10.3390/educsci11110669

nodes.label: Interpreting data scientifically
nodes.citation: OECD. (2013). PISA 2012 Assessment and Analytical Framework: Mathematics, Reading, Science, Problem Solving and Financial Literacy, PISA. Paris: OECD Publishing. https://doi.org/10.1787/9789264190511-en

nodes.label: Explain and predict phenomena
nodes.text: Explain and predict phenomena, formulate [real world situations] in mathematical terms
nodes.citation: OECD. (2018). The Future of Education and Skills: Education 2030. Position Paper. http://www.oecd.org/education/2030/E2030%20Position%20Paper%20(05.04.2018).pdf

nodes.label: Reasoning about uncertainty
nodes.citation: OECD. (2018). The Future of Education and Skills: Education 2030. Position Paper. http://www.oecd.org/education/2030/E2030%20Position%20Paper%20(05.04.2018).pdf

nodes.label: Probabilistic reasoning
nodes.citation: Kind, P., & Osborne, J. (2017). Styles of Scientific Reasoning: A Cultural Rationale for Science Education? Science Education, 101(1), 8–31. https://doi.org/10.1002/sce.21251

nodes.label: Historical significance interpretation
nodes.text: Historical significance: interpreting and assigning significance to a historical process; creating the meaning within a historical narrative
nodes.citation: Seixas, P., & Morton, T. (2012). The Big Six Historical Thinking Concepts. Toronto: Nelson.

nodes.label: Develop new structures
nodes.text: Develop new unique structures, systems, models, approaches, ideas
nodes.citation: Wrigley, C., & Straker, K. (2015). Design Thinking pedagogy: The Educational Design Ladder. Innovations in Education and Teaching International, 54(4), 374–385. https://doi.org/10.1080/14703297.2015.1108214

nodes.label: Develop plans or procedures
nodes.text: Develop plans or procedures, design solutions, integrate methods, resources, ideas, parts; create teams or new approaches
nodes.citation: Wrigley, C., & Straker, K. (2015). Design Thinking pedagogy: The Educational Design Ladder. Innovations in Education and Teaching International, 54(4), 374–385. https://doi.org/10.1080/14703297.2015.1108214

nodes.citation: Farran, E. K. (2019). Spatial Ability as a Gateway to STEM Success. https://my.chartered.college/impact_article/spatial-ability-as-a-gateway-to-stem-success/; Newcombe, N. (2016). nodes.text: interpreting views of three-dimensional scenes from various perspectives and constructing representations of shapes
